required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Post Marketing Survey Study to Evaluate the Safety and Effectiveness of Intelence
clinical_study.official_title: Regulatory Post Marketing Surveillance of Intelence Tablet

oversight_info.authority: Republic of Korea: Food and Drug Administration

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the safety data of etravirine in a natural clinical practice.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a non-interventional (a scientific study to make a clear and easy understanding of the cause and effect relationship), prospective (in which the participants are first identified and then followed forward as time passes), consecutive survey for collecting safety and efficacy data of etravirine in treatment of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) in a natural clinical practice.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Prospective

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients with adverse events
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 30 days from end of treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients with viral load
Number of patients with CD4 T-cell count

arm_group.description: Patients having Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) will be taking etravirine as per recommended doses.

intervention.description: This is an observational study. Etravirine 200 mg will be adminstered twice daily in patients with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).

study_pop.textblock: The study population will include patients who are diagnosed with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS), and who are prescribed with etravirine for treatment of AIDS.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are prescribed with etravirine for treatment of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Known hypersensitivity to Intelence
- Intelence coadministered with medicinal products that are highly dependent on CYP3A and CYP2C9 for clearance
- Patients with galactose intoralance, Lapp lactase deficiency, and glucose-galactose malabsorption

overall_official.last_name: Janssen Korea, Ltd., Korea Clinical Trial
